  <div id="container">
    <div class="docs markdown"><div class="pilwrap" id="contributing-to-recharts">
  <h1>
    <a href="#contributing-to-recharts" name="contributing-to-recharts" class="pilcrow"></a>
Contributing to Recharts
  </h1>
</div>
<p>We'd love for you to contribute to our source code and to make Recharts even better than it is today!</p>
<p>If you want to know how to develop then check out the <a href="/DEVELOPING.md.html">Development Guide</a>.</p>
<p>Here are the guidelines we'd like you to follow:</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="ongoing-initiatives">
  <h2>
    <a href="#ongoing-initiatives" name="ongoing-initiatives" class="pilcrow"></a>
Ongoing Initiatives
  </h2>
</div>
<p>We use Github Discussion to organize our discussion along new initiatives and organize ourselves. Please do check the <a href="https://github.com/recharts/recharts/discussions/categories/announcements">announcements</a> section for an overview of recent initiatives.</p>
<p>Also feel free to join us on Slack: https://recharts.slack.com/archives/C042Q5K5UDC</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="issues-and-bugs">
  <h2>
    <a href="#issues-and-bugs" name="issues-and-bugs" class="pilcrow"></a>
<a name="issues"></a>Issues and Bugs
  </h2>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="where-to-find-known-issues">
  <h3>
    <a href="#where-to-find-known-issues" name="where-to-find-known-issues" class="pilcrow"></a>
Where to Find Known Issues
  </h3>
</div>
<p>We will be using <a href="https://github.com/recharts/recharts/issues">GitHub Issues</a> for our bugs and feature requests. We will keep a close eye on this and try to make it clear when we have an internal fix in progress. Before filing a new task, try to make sure your problem doesn't already exist.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="reporting-new-issues">
  <h3>
    <a href="#reporting-new-issues" name="reporting-new-issues" class="pilcrow"></a>
Reporting New Issues
  </h3>
</div>
<p>The best way to get your bug fixed is to provide a reduced test case. codesandbox provide a way to give live examples. You can fork our example in <a href="https://recharts.github.io/">recharts.github.io</a> to show your case.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="testing">
  <h2>
    <a href="#testing" name="testing" class="pilcrow"></a>
<a name="testing"></a>Testing
  </h2>
</div>
<p>We do cherish tests. They help us move swiftly, and release with confidence.
In our repo, you will find three types of tests: Unit tests, rendering tests with RTL, and user interaction tests in storybook.
Wherever possible we prefer the simplest tests - unit tests. Only where needed / useful we would use RTL or storybook tests.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="unit-tests">
  <h3>
    <a href="#unit-tests" name="unit-tests" class="pilcrow"></a>
Unit tests
  </h3>
</div>
<p>When writing new code, aim for 100% unit test code coverage.</p>
<p>When implementing a new feature we would prefer to extract pure helper function for data processing.
Such functions are found in a few utils files. An example is <code>test/util/ShallowEqual.spec.ts</code>.</p>
<p>Unit testing in recharts has some specialties, please see <a href="test/README.md.html">Recharts unit tests README</a> for more information.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="react-testing-library">
  <h3>
    <a href="#react-testing-library" name="react-testing-library" class="pilcrow"></a>
React Testing Library
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Some behaviour must be tested upon rendering, such as interactions between components (Line, Tooltip), see <code>test/component/Tooltip.visibility.spec.tsx</code> for an example.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="storybook-test-runner">
  <h3>
    <a href="#storybook-test-runner" name="storybook-test-runner" class="pilcrow"></a>
Storybook Test Runner
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Storybook also has a great interface for adding tests. By default every story in storybook is a smoke test (rendering without error logs means the test passed). Additionally, it is possible to add actual tests as play functions with an assert to a story. This will often be easier than using React Testing Library, because the natural test debugging tool is Storybook itself. See for example <code>storybook/stories/Examples/cartesian/ReferenceLine/ReferenceLineIfOverflow.stories.tsx</code></p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="mutation-tests">
  <h3>
    <a href="#mutation-tests" name="mutation-tests" class="pilcrow"></a>
Mutation tests
  </h3>
</div>
<p>We have <a href="https://stryker-mutator.io/docs/">stryker</a> installed and ready to use for mutation testing.</p>
<p>If you want to run mutation test be aware that these may take hours! A single file will take 15 minutes or more.</p>
<p>To run, update the list of checked files in <code>./stryker.config.mjs</code> and then run with <code>npm run test-mutation</code>.</p>
<p>You will find test output in your console, and also HTML report in the <code>./reports</code> folder.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="pull-requests">
  <h2>
    <a href="#pull-requests" name="pull-requests" class="pilcrow"></a>
<a name="pr"></a>Pull Requests
  </h2>
</div>
<p><strong>Working on your first Pull Request?</strong> You can learn how from this <em>free</em> series <a href="https://app.egghead.io/playlists/how-to-contribute-to-an-open-source-project-on-github">How to Contribute to an Open Source Project on GitHub</a></p>
<p><em>Before</em> submitting a pull request, please make sure the following is doneâ€¦</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Search <a href="https://github.com/recharts/recharts/pulls">GitHub</a> for an open or closed Pull Request that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fork the repo and create your branch from <code>main</code>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If you have added functionality or changed existing functionality, be sure to add a test. Ideally a unit test for helper function, or a test that includes rendering with RTL.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If you've changed APIs, make sure that the stories in Storybook are working as expected.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ensure the test suite passes (<code>npm run test</code>).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Make sure your code lints (<code>npm run lint</code>) - we've done our best to make sure these rules match our internal linting guidelines.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="pilwrap" id="code-guide">
  <h2>
    <a href="#code-guide" name="code-guide" class="pilcrow"></a>
<a name="code"></a>Code Guide
  </h2>
</div>
<p>Our linter will catch most styling issues that may exist in your code.
You can check the status of your code styling by running: <code>npm run lint</code></p>
<p>However, there are still some styles that the linter cannot pick up. If you are unsure about something, looking at <a href="https://github.com/airbnb/javascript">Airbnb's Style Guide</a> will guide you in the right direction.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="types">
  <h2>
    <a href="#types" name="types" class="pilcrow"></a>
Types
  </h2>
</div>
<p>We use TypeScript for type safety. Some rules to follow:</p>
<ul>
<li>Never use <code>any</code> type. Implicit or explicit.</li>
<li>Prefer <code>unknown</code> over <code>any</code>. Refine the type.</li>
<li>Type your function parameters and return values explicitly, do not rely on implicit any or inference. Exceptions are React components and trivial functions where the types are obvious.</li>
<li>Do not use <code>as</code> type assertions, ever. The only exception is <code>as const</code>.</li>
</ul>
<div class="pilwrap" id="license">
  <h2>
    <a href="#license" name="license" class="pilcrow"></a>
<a name="license"></a>License
  </h2>
</div>
<p>By contributing to Recharts, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under its MIT license.</p>
</div>
  </div>
